Number of microfilm readers available in the searchroom.
num
workPlaces
Optional, repeatable
Multilingual Services
[text]
services
Optional, repeatable
Generic Name
An element for encoding generic names.
part
holdings
An element that can be used where a name cannot be classified as persname, corpname or famname. Aim to uniquely identify the entity, adding dates or additional information if useful.
Adding names to holdings information can highlight particular areas of strength of the institution's holdings.
Optional, repeatable
Name Entry
An element containing a name entry for a corporate body, person, or family.
part (1..n), useDates (0..n)
identity, nameEntrySet
Within identity, the element nameEntry is used to record a name by which the repository described in the EAG instance is known.
When nameEntry occurs within nameEntrySet it is used to record two or more forms of a name, for example official and non-official forms of the name in different languages and/or scripts.
Each form of the name is recorded in a separate nameEntry element.
Each nameEntry must contain at least one part element. Within nameEntry each of the component parts of a name may be recorded in a separate part element.
The nameEntry element may also contain a useDates element to indicate the dates the name was used.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: The status attribute may be used to indicate whether the nameEntry is an authorized or alternative form of the name.

The scriptOfElement and languageOfElement attributes can be used to specify the script and language of each name recorded in several nameEntry elements, especially when used in parallel to each other.

div.p: Within identity: one of nameEntry or nameEntrySet required, repeatable
Within nameEntrySet: two or more nameEntry-s required, repeatable
Name Entry Set

An optional child element of identity used as a wrapper element for two or more nameEntry elements representing different forms of the same name (e.g., official and non-official forms of the name in different languages and/or scripts).
nameEntry (2..n), useDates (0..n)
identity

A wrapper element used to group two or more nameEntry elements representing parallel or other forms of the name for the same repository which are used at the same time (e.g., official and non-official forms of the name in different languages and/or scripts).
The nameEntrySet element may contain a useDates element to indicate the dates the set of name forms was used.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:
Within identity: one of nameEntry or nameEntrySet required, repeatable
Number or amount
Concrete number or amount including the respective unit of measurement.
[text]
computerPlaces, extent, lengthOfShelves, microfilmPlaces, repositoryArea, workPlaces
A specific number or amount. Must include the respective unit of measurement in the accompanying attribute unit.
It is a required element if the elements are used where it can occur. For example, if you use extent or lengthOfShelves then you need to provide a numerical amount.
Required, not repeatable
Object XML Wrap
An optional child element of relation, setComponent, and source that allows for the inclusion of an XML element from any XML namespace other than EAC-CPF.
[any element from any namespace]
relation, setComponent, source
A wrapper element that provides a place to express data in any XML encoding language.
To facilitate interoperability the XML should conform to an open, standard XML schema and a namespace attribute should be present on the root element referencing the namespace of the standard.
It is also possible to encode data in XML without a namespace within the objectXML element.

objectXMLWrap may be used to store related XML data locally rather than linking to external resources in order to facilitate processing or in cases where the related data may not be reliably accessible.
Optional, not repeatable
Opening times
Opening times of the repository.
[text]
timetable

Provide opening times for your reading room. It is preferable to provide full days and times in the 24 hour clock, e.g. Monday-Wednesday 09.00-17.00. You may link to your own page with opening times or with more detailed information. It is better to link to your own page if that is more likely to be kept up-to-date.
Required, repeatable

eag:timetable.eag:opening: Consulta en sala: de lunes a viernes de 8.30 a 14.30 horas. Información y asuntos generales: de lunes a viernes de 8.30 a 14:30 horas

div.p: Other Agency Code
An optional child element of maintenanceAgency that provides an alternative code for the institution or service responsible for the EAC-CPF instance.
[text]
maintenanceAgency

Use otherAgencyCode to provide an alternative and/or local code that represents the institution or service responsible for the creation, maintenance, and/or dissemination of the EAC-CPF instance. Any code other than that given in agencyCode may be provided in otherAgencyCode. The addition of an ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code as the prefix to a local code is recommended to ensure international uniqueness.

list.item: Use localType to specify the type of code being provided.
Use status to encode whether the otherAgencyCode is an authorized or alternative code.

div.p: Optional, repeatable
Other Record Identifier
An optional child element of control that encodes any local identifier for the EAC-CPF instance.
[text]
control

otherRecordId can be used to record an identifier that is an alternative to the mandatory identifier provided in recordId. These might include the identifiers of merged EAC-CPF instances representing the same CPF entity or those of records that are no longer current but had some part in the history and maintenance of the EAC-CPF instance.

list.item: Use localType to identify the institution or service responsible for providing the associated record identifier, if not the same as that given in maintenanceAgency.

div.p: Optional, repeatable
Other repository identifier
Any other identifier used by the institution being described.
[text]
identity
Any other identifier used by the institution being described, not necessarily compliant with ISO 15511 as recommended in repositoryId and its attribute repositoryCode.
Optional, repeatable
Other Repository Type

A required child element of otherRepositoryTypes used to encode alternative repository types such as translations or specifications of respectively additions to the predefined values used in repositoryType.
date or dateRange or dateSet (0..1), descriptiveNote (0..1), placeName (0..n), term (1..n)
otherRepositoryTypes

The types of institutions with archival holdings might be defined by a regional or national archives association. If existing, enter terms in accordance with such conventions. Terms may be drawn from controlled vocabularies or may be natural language terms.

otherRepositoryType must include at least one term element, where the type of repository is encoded. term can be repeated within otherRepositoryType to include translations of the same term. Use the languageOfElement attribute to identify the language used in each term.

Associated date(s) (date, dateRange, or dateSet) and place(s) (placeName) may be included to further constrain the term's meaning. A descriptiveNote element may be included if a fuller textual explanation is needed.
Multiple otherRepositoryType elements may be grouped within an otherRepositoryTypes element.
The prescribed order of all child elements is:
Required, repeatable

div.p: Other Repository Types
An optional child element of identity used to bundle together one or more otherRepositoryType elements.
descriptiveNote (0..1), otherRepositoryType (1..n)
identity

Use the element otherRepositoryTypes to provide more specific terms to the ones predefined for repositoryType or to provide translations of or equivalents to the predefined terms in your country's context.
otherRepositoryTypes requires at least one otherRepositoryType element to be present and includes the optional, not repeatable descriptiveNote element for further explanatory text if necessary.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:
Optional, not repeatable

div.p: Paragraph
A general purpose element used to encode blocks of text.
[text], reference (0..n), span (0..n)
biogHist, descriptiveNote, generalContext, structureOrGenealogy

Use p for blocks of text. A paragraph may be a subdivision of a larger composition or it may exist alone. It is usually typographically distinguished: A line space is often left blank before it; the text begins on a new line; and the first letter of the first word may be indented, enlarged, or both.
Within descriptiveNote: required, repeatable.
Within all other parents: optional, repeatable.
Part

A required and repeatable child of nameEntry corpName, famName, genreForm, name, persName, subject, and targetEntity used to distinguish components of the archival institution's name, or the name of a related entity.
[text]
nameEntry, corpName, famName, genreForm, name, persName, subject, targetEntity

Within nameEntry each of the components of a name may be recorded in a separate part element. part may also contain the full name of the entity when it is not possible to distinguish the different components of the name.
part cannot be empty and requires at least one non-whitespace character, such as a hyphen, if no actual name can be given.
Within targetEntity the name or term for the related entity is encoded within part elements.

list.item: The designation of the information contained in the part can be specified by the attribute localType.

div.p: Required, repeatable
Personal Name
An element for identifying a personal name.
part
holdings

Provide a personal name, preferably the full name with life dates. Epithets and titles can also be included to help to uniquely identify the person. Adding personal names to holdings information can highlight particular areas of strength of the institution's holdings.
The attribute localType can be used to structure the name.
If the name is taken from a source such as VIAF or Wikidata then the attribute valueURI can be used to provide the permalink, along with vocabularySource and vocabularySourceURI.
Optional, repeatable
Photograph Allowance
Statement whether it is allowed to take photographs of records in the searchroom.
[text]
searchroom
Optional, repeatable
Place
To provide all relevant addresses for the institution with archival holdings, both physical and electronic.(ISDIAH, chapter 5.2.1)
address or contact or geographicCoordinates or placeName or placeRole (1..n), date or dateRange or dateSet (0..1), descriptiveNote (0..1)
chronItem, chronItemSet, places, relation
A place element is a wrapper element used to encode information about the physical as well as possibly available electronic address.
place must include at least one of address, contact, geographicCoordinates, placeName or placeRole.

placeName may be used to encode the historical or local name of the building in which the institution is located. The placeRole element is available to specify the nature of the connection of the place to the institution. Terms in placeName and placeRole may be drawn from controlled vocabularies or may be natural language terms. These controlled vocabularies can be identified with the vocabularySource and vocabularySourceURI attributes.

The address element is available for specifying a visitors' address and, if different, a postal address, consisting at least of the street name and number, postal code, city, country. The contact element is available for specifying a digital address or other contact information.

If applicable further contact details can be included such as a region or subregion or a specific district of the city. Note that the inclusion of the region or other administrative levels depends on the administrative structure of the country where the institution being described is located. The addresses of additional repositories can be included in this element, too. Together with electronic mail addresses, a website address and a map service/address should ideally be provided.

Associated date or date range (date, dateRange, or dateSet) information may be included to further constrain the place's meaning. A descriptiveNote may be included if a fuller explanation of the significance of the place to the insitution described is needed.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: One or more of address, contact, geographicCoordinates, placeName, and placeRole
One of date, dateRange, or dateSet

div.p: Within places: required, repeatable.
Within chronItem: optional, not repeatable.
Within chronItemSet and relation: optional, repeatable.

div.p: Place Name
An optional child element of place used to encode the name of a place or geographic feature that is related to the CPF entity described.
[text]
function, legalStatus, localDescription, mandate, occupation, otherEntityType, place

placeName should be identified by the proper noun that commonly designates the place, natural feature, or political jurisdiction. It is recommended that place names be taken from authorized vocabularies.

Within place, a companion placeRole is strongly recommended to describe the nature of the address. Furthermore a companion geographicCoordinates is available beside placeName, when used within place, to encode latitude, longitude and altitude information.
One of placeName, placeRole, geographicCoordinates, address, or contact is required within place.

The placeName element is repeatable. It is strongly recommended that within place, the placeName element be repeated only to represent the same place name in various languages, with an accompanying languageOfElement attribute.

list.item: The vocabularySource attribute may be used to indicate the controlled vocabulary from which the placeName term is derived.

div.p: Optional, repeatable
Place Role
An optional child element of place used to identify the contextual role the place has in relation to the archival institution (visitor's or postal address).
[text]
place
placeRole provides a contextual role for the place described in connection to the archival institution, specially visitor's address or postal address.
One of placeRole, placeName, geographicCoordinates, address, or contact is required within place.

list.item: The vocabularySource attribute may be used to indicate the controlled vocabulary from which the placeRole is derived.

Places

descriptiveNote (0..n), place (1..n)
description

Use the mandatory places element to group together one or more occurrences of place. places must include at least one place element. A descriptiveNote element may be included if a fuller textual explanation is needed.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

El acceso a los Archivos y la consulta de los fondos documentales del patrimonio documental español es libre y gratuito, sin perjuicio de que los ciudadanos tengan que acreditar su identidad. Para ello, cada usuario tendrá que facilitar alguno de los siguientes documentos que acrediten la identidad, según sea el caso: - El Documento Nacional de Identidad (DNI), en el caso de los españoles. - El Número de Identificación de Extranjeros (NIE), si fuera un extranjero residente en España. - El pasaporte, para los extranjeros no residentes en España o Documento de Identidad de ciudadanos comunitarios.

div.p: Record Identifier
A required child element of control that designates a unique identifier for the EAC-CPF instance.
[text]
control

recordId is used for recording a unique identifier for the EAC-CPF instance. The institution assigning the identifier ensures uniqueness of the recordId value within the archival descriptions under its control. A globally unique identifier may be constructed within recordId according to various external protocols (i.e. HTTP URI, DOI, PURL, or UUID), or in combination with agencyCode, which is an optional element within maintenanceAgency.
recordId cannot be empty. Any alternative or additional record identifiers may be recorded in otherRecordId.

list.item: Use agencyCode in combination with recordId to provide a globally unique identifier for the EAC-CPF instance.

div.p: Reference
An element that cites an external resource.
[text], span (0..n)
abstract, chronItem, chronItemSet, conventionDeclaration, event, eventDescription, item, localTypeDeclaration, p, rightsDeclaration, source

An element used for referencing external resources that have been used to compile the EAC-CPF instance, that provide additional context to the EAC-CPF instance, or that identify rules or conventions that have been applied.

reference is a required child element of conventionDeclaration, localTypeDeclaration, and rightsDeclaration for identifying any rules and conventions applied in the compilation of the description. It is also a required child element of source, used to identify any sources used in compiling the description. source may include multiple child reference elements.

reference is an optional child element of abstract, chronItem, chronItemSet, event, eventDescription, item, and p where it is used to reference any external resources that provide additional context to the content of that element.

list.item: Use href to link to the cited resource.
reference is used for external linking only. If any internal linking is required within the EAC-CPF instance, use the target attribute.

div.p: Within conventionDeclaration, localTypeDeclaration, rightsDeclaration: required, not repeatable
Within source: required, repeatable
Within abstract, chronItem, chronItemSet, event, eventDescription, item, p: optional, repeatable

div.p: Relation
A required child element of relations for describing a relationship between the entity described in the EAC-CPF instance and a related entity.
date or dateRange or dateSet (0..1), descriptiveNote (0..1), objectXMLWrap (0..1), place (0..n), relationType (0..n), targetEntity (1..1), targetRole (0..n)
relations

relation records descriptive information about a relationship between the entity being described and a related entity, such as: a corporate body, person, or family; a function; or an archival, bibliographic, or other resource.

Use the required child element targetEntity to provide a textual identification of the related entity, such as a name or a title. Use the optional child element relationType to specify the type of relation. Use the optional child element targetRole to specify the role of the related entity. It is recommended that the terms used in relationType, targetEntity, and targetRole be taken from an authorized vocabulary.

Use objectXMLWrap to embed XML documenting the related entity from any namespace. Use date, dateRange, or dateSet for specifying the time period of the relationship and place for relevant location information. descriptiveNote may be included for more detailed specifications or explanations of the relationship.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: One of date, dateRange, or dateSet
One or more of place, relationType, and targetRole

div.p: Required, repeatable
Relations

An optional child element of cpfDescription that groups one or more relation elements, which identify external entities and characterize the nature of their relationships to the entity being described.
descriptiveNote (0..1), relation (1..n)
cpfDescription
A wrapper element that groups together one or more relation elements, each of which encodes a specific relationship.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:
Optional, not repeatable
Relation Type
A child element of relation used to specify the type of relation that the entity being described within the EAC-CPF instance has to the targetEntity.
[text]
relation
Use relationType within relation to specify the type of relation that the entity being described has to the targetEntity.
The relationType element contains a textual description of the relation. It is recommended that values used in relationType be taken from an authorized vocabulary.
Optional, repeatable
Repositories
Wrapper for the different repositories of the institution.
image (0..n), relations (0..1), repository (2..n)
eag

Within an EAG instance, either a single repository element or the repositories element - combining two or more repository elements - has to be present. Depending on the administrative structure of an institution with archival holdings, the one or the other option might be more appropriate to describe the institution. Use repositories e.g. in case an institution has several locations, which hold different types of material or result from several formerly independent institutions.
repositories requires at least two repository elements. If the institution only consists of one repository, use the single repository element instead.

Use the optional relations element to provide information about relationships to other entities that refer to all repository-s of the institution. Use the optional image element to e.g. provide a link to a logo or to images of the archival institution etc.
The prescribed order of all child elements is:
Within eag: one of repository or repositories required, not repeatable

div.p: Repository
Information on one archival repository.
description (1..1), identity (1..1), image (0..n), relations (0..1)
eag, repositories

Within an EAG instance, either a single repository element - representing an archival institution as a whole - or the repositories element - combining two or more repository elements describing parts of the archival institution - has to be present. Depending on the administrative structure of an institution with archival holdings, the one or the other option might be more appropriate to describe the institution.

The required child elements identity and description encode the name or names related to the repository and descriptive the information about it. The optional image element can be used to include the logo or other imagery representation of the repository. The relation with other entities can be represented in the relations element.
Use repositories instead of a single repository element in case an institution has several locations, which hold different types of material or result from several formerly independent institutions.
The prescribed order of all child elements is:
Within eag: one of repository or repositories required, not repeatable
Within repositories: required, repeatable

eag:contact.eag:contactLine: The Special Collections Reading Room is located in Room 02.3 (Basement Floor) of the J.B. Priestley Library on city campus.

eag:access.question: yes (conditions apply)
eag:access.eag:accessConditions: Special Collections are open to, and intended for, anyone who might benefit from using them. However, space and staffing constraints mean that appointments are required. Access is subject to preservation requirements and must also conform to the restrictions of the Data Protection Act and any other appropriate legislation.
eag:access.eag:useConditions: See website for information on using our holdings.

eag:timetable.eag:opening: See website for information on opening hours.

eag:description.eag:accessibility: The Reading Room is accessible by lifts and level floors. However the layout of Floor 02 pre-dates modern standards and can be difficult for very large or long wheelchairs. We can book a back-up room with level access if necessary.

eag:biogHist.eag:p: The present staffed Special Collections service was created when the University Library received access funding from the Research Support Libraries Programme in 2000.Initially we concentrated on mapping the collections, and establishing policies and procedures for preservation, disaster control and collection development.

Over the last few years, the focus of our work has shifted towards marketing, outreach and fundraising, especially encouraging virtual engagement with the collections. Our achievements were recently recognised by the Archive Accreditation Scheme: we are the first English university to receive this prestigious award.

Since establishing the service, we have acquired other exciting resources, such as the Commonwealth Archives and the Jacquetta Hawkes Archive, and enriched those already here, particularly the J. B. Priestley Archive. We are very grateful for the help we have received from colleagues and volunteers over the past years.

eag:descriptiveNote.eag:p: Special Collections at the University of Bradford holds over 100 collections of rare books and archives on the history of the University, Bradford, Yorkshire, history, politics, literature, archaeology and much more, our best-known being the Archive of J.B. Priestley. Our collections are open to everyone and include manuscripts, letters, photographs, artworks, newspapers, maps, pamphlets, objects, pipes (Priestley's) and digital files.

eag:searchroom.question: yes
eag:searchroom.eag:photographAllowance: We encourage visitors to use their own devices to take images for personal research use. This is at the discretion of the staff member on duty and subject to copyright and care.
eag:searchroom.eag:advancedOrders: Available. Send us details of the materials you’d like to consult. We can have them out ready for you, so you can begin your research at once.

eag:services.eag:internetAccess: If you wish to use wi-fi, register with one of our networks for quick access on the day.

eag:descriptiveNote.eag:p: Special Collections offers photocopying and digitisation services for enquirers who for practical or legal reasons cannot take advantage of personal digital photography. We need a declaration form and payment before we can go ahead with copying. Remote enquirers should contact us to obtain a quotation for likely costs before completing their declaration.

eag:recreationalServices.eag:exhibition: The PaxCat Project: bringing peace archives to life

div.p: Repository Area
Information about the size of the repository area within the building.
num
buildingInfo
This element is normally used to give the size of the storage areas, which helps researchers to get a sense of the volume of the holdings.
Optional, repeatable
Repository identifier
Element meant to gather the countryCode and repositoryCode of the archival institution to provide a unique and ideally persistent identifier for the repository being described.
[empty]
identity

Provide a unique numeric or alphanumeric code identifying the repository using the required repositoryCode attribute. Ideally, this identifier is compliant with the standard ISO 15511:2011, which can be specified using the attribute repositoryEncoding within control. As such, the identifier would be made up of two components: a two-letter country code (according to the standard ISO 3166-1) or a three-to-four letter code for another type of registring organisation, plus a numeric or alpha-numeric institution's identifier separated by a hyphen. The maximum length of both parts combined would be up to 16 characters.
The country code according to ISO 3166-1 will have to be provided in all cases using the mandatory countryCode attribute.

In addition to being compliant with ISO 15511:2011, an institution's identifier may be an officially registered ISIL code, effectively resulting in global uniqueness of the identifier as a whole. Whether or not a repository identifier is registered by an authorisation agency, can be indicated by using the status attribute with the possible values "authorized" respectively "alternative".

Identifiers complying with national, regional or local standards, rules or guidelines can be given here as well, in case no identifier compliant with ISO 15511 exists. It would then be recommended to use the attribute repositoryEncoding within control with the value "otherRepositoryEncoding". Alternatively, seeing that repositoryId is only optional, you can also use the parallel element otherRepositoryCode where there are no specific requirements regarding the format of its content.
Optional, not repeatable
Role of the Repository
Describes the role of the repository.
[text]
description

repositoryRole can be used to describe the managerial or administrative role of repository, especially when describing several repositories that are part of one institution. Possible roles are "headquarters", "branch", "department", "district office" or "sub-office". You could also use something like "interim archive" for a temporary location.

Do not confuse with repositoryType, which comes with a predefined list of terms, or its sibling otherRepositoryType. These tags are used to capture types of archival institutions as defined by their mandate, the context they operate in and the type of organisation(s) that they function as an archive for.
If you take your values from a source, you can record it using the vocabulary attributes valueURI, vocabularySource and vocabularySourceURI.
Optional, repeatable
Type of institution
Describes the type of archival institution.
[empty]
identity
Describes the type of repository with a predefined list in the attribute value; available terms are:
"nationalArchives", i.e. archival institutions that hold public records of government institutions on the national level

"regionalArchives, i.e. archival institutions that hold public records of government institutions on an administrative level that is between the national and the local levels; depending on a country's administrative system this type might not be relevant for all countries; or an institution could fall into this category in one country, but rather would fit into the category of "localArchives" in another country
"localArchives", e.g. county or local authority archives and municipal archives, i.e. archival institutions that hold public records of government institutions on a local level

"specialisedGovernmentArchives", i.e. archival institutions that hold records of institutions that are subdivisions of governmental bodies, that are funded by government, or related to government in some other administrative or organisational form; use the controlled access terms available with holdings to indicate an institution's subject specialism

"specialisedNongovernmentalArchives", i.e. archival institutions that hold records of institutions that are independent from government, e.g. archives of other cultural (heritage) institutions, archives of political parties, of popular/labour movements, associations, agencies and foundations, archives of the media, archives of research institutions, etc.; depending on how such archives are managed and depending on the organisations they function as an archive for, other types could apply to institutions in this category as well, such as "communityArchives" in case the archive is managed privately or by volunteers or "businessArchives", e.g. for the public archives of a broadcasting company; use the controlled access terms available with holdings to indicate an institution's subject specialism
"personalAndFamilyArchives", i.e. archives of (noble) families or (prominent) persons that are kept by non-governmental organisations or privately
"businessArchives", i.e. archives of businesses that are mainly kept for the internal purpose of the organisation, but might also be accessible to the public
"religiousInstitutionsArchives", i.e. archives of religious institutions, organisations, associations, including churches, mosques, synagogues and other types of temples
"universityArchives", i.a. archives of universities (and other institutions of higher education depending on the national context)
"nonUniversityEducationArchives", i.e. archives of other institutions of the educational sector that do not classify as universities, e.g. schools
"internationalArchives", i.e.archives of international organisations, e.g. EU organisations, UN organisations, International Red Cross, Amnesty International, Doctors without Frontiers, etc.

"communityArchives", i.e. archives that are (often) run by volunteers (groups), that hold materials relating to less represented/marginalised groups of people whether that’s by nationality, heritage, religion, gender, sexual orientation, age, etc.

Use the element otherRepositoryType to provide more specific terms to the ones predefined for repositoryType or to provide translations of or equivalents to the predefined terms in your country's context.
Do not confuse with the element repositoryRole that decsribes the role of a repository within the organisational structure of an archival institution.
Optional, repeatable
Representation
An optional child element of control for recording a link to a deliverable version of the EAC-CPF instance or to the XML version of the EAC-CPF instance itself.
[text]
control
Use representation to record a link to a deliverable version of an EAC-CPF instance, for example an HTML or PDF version, or to the XML version of the EAC-CPF instance itself.

list.item: Use href to specify a link to a deliverable version of the EAC-CPF instance.
Use localType to differentiate between multiple representation elements.
Use otherRecordId to provide any local identifier for the EAC-CPF instance that does not link to a deliverable version.

eag:descriptiveNote.eag:p: For consultation on site, microfilm copies of records that would otherwise be at risk are being made available in the reading room at specified work stations.

Furthermore, parts of the holdings can be made available to researchers on site and as a service in either the form of photocopies or as digital representations. The latter are also available on demand in case the documents of interest have not been digitised yet. More details on related fees can be found online or by contacting the reading room.

Rights Declaration
An optional child element of control that indicates a standard rights statement associated with the EAC-CPF instance.
descriptiveNote (0..1), reference (1..1), shortCode (0..1)
control

Use rightsDeclaration to provide structured information about the usage rights of the EAC-CPF instance. rightsDeclaration should only be used to reference shared published licenses, such as Creative Commons, RightsStatements.org, and published locally-defined licenses.
reference must be used to provide a machine-readable reference to a license statement (for example, a dereferenceable URI). It may also be used to encode the name of the license statement.
shortCode may be used to provide the abbreviated name for the rights statement. The value of shortCode should align with the rights statement referenced by reference and descriptiveNote.
descriptiveNote may be used to provide a human-readable description of the license statement.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

div.p: Short Code
An optional element for encoding the shortened form of a word or phrase.
[text]
conventionDeclaration, localTypeDeclaration, rightsDeclaration
Used to record the shortened form of a word or phrase, for example, an acronym.

Use shortCode within conventionDeclaration or localTypeDeclaration to identify the code for a thesaurus, controlled vocabulary, or another standard used in creating the EAC-CPF description. Use within rightsDeclaration to provide an abbreviated name for the rights statement.
To improve interoperability, it is recommended that the value be selected from an authorized list of codes such as the MARC Code List (http://www.loc.gov/marc/sourcelist/).
Optional, not repeatable
Social Media
Information about social media used by the repository or institution.
[text]
description
Add information about accounts on social media. It is recommended to provide the URL using the href attribute.
Optional, repeatable
Source
A required child element of sources used to identify a particular source of evidence used for the establishment of the description of the CPF entity in the EAC-CPF instance.
citedRange (0..n), descriptiveNote (0..1), objectXMLWrap (0..1), reference (1..n)
sources

Use source to cite a published resource used in describing the CPF entity. Use the required child element referenceto include a textual identification of the reference. In the case of online sources, use href with reference to provide a URI.
Use the optional child element citedRange to point to a specific location within a source.
Use the optional descriptiveNote for any additional notes about the source. Use the optional objectXMLWrap to embed XML documenting the source from any namespace.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:
Required, repeatable
Sources
An optional child element of control that groups one or more sources of evidence used in the description of the CPF entity in the EAC-CPF instance.
descriptiveNote (0..1), source (1..n)
control
Use sources to bind together one or more source elements. sources must include at least one source element.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: Use base to specify a URI (other than the base URI of the EAC-CPF instance) to be used for resolving relative URIs within sources or descendant elements.

div.p: Optional, not repeatable
span
Specifies the beginning and the end of a span of text.
[text]
abstract, event, eventDescription, head, item, reference, p
span is an optional formatting element for distinguishing words or phrases that are intentionally stressed or emphasized for linguistic effect or identifying some qualities of the words or phrases.

list.item: Use the optional style attribute to affect an arbitrary stylistic difference.
Use the optional localType attribute to identify qualities of words or phrases.

div.p: Optional, repeatable
Structure or Genealogy
An optional child element of description used to describe internal administrative structure(s) of an archival institution.
description

structureOrGenealogy encodes information expressing the internal administrative structure(s) of an archival institution and the dates of any changes to that structure that are significant to understanding the way that insitution conducted affairs (such as dated organization charts).

The optional list element may be used to accommodate greater complexity in expressing or representing the structure(s) or genealogy being described. head may be used to encode a title or caption. A simpler discursive expression of the structure(s) or genealogy may be encoded as one or more p elements.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: One or both of list or p.

div.p: Optional, repeatable
Subject
An element for topics represented in the materials being described.
part
holdings
Adding subjects to holdings information can highlight particular areas of strength of the institution's holdings.

If the subject is taken from a thesaurus such as Unesco or Library of Congress Subject Headings then vocabularySource can be used to specify this, and the vocabularySourceURI can give the URI of the source being used.
Optional, repeatable
Target Entity
A required child element of relation used to identify the entity that is being targeted by the relation.
part (1..n)
relation

list.label: audience
conventionDeclarationReference
id
languageOfElement
maintenanceEventReference
scriptOfElement
sourceReference
target
targetType
list.item: Required (values limited to: agent, corporateBody, family, function, person, resource)
list.label: valueURI
vocabularySource
vocabularySourceURI

div.p: targetEntity is used within relation to identify an entity that is related to the subject of the EAC-CPF instance.
targetEntity must include at least one part element, encoding the name or term for the related entity.

list.item: Use the required targetType, to identity the type of entity related to in targetEntity, using one of the following values: "agent", "corporateBody", "family", "function", "person", or "resource".

div.p: Required, not repeatable
Target Role
An optional child element of relation used to specify the role of a related entity towards the CPF entity being described.
[text]
relation
targetRole is used with relation to specify the role of a related entity towards the CPF entity being described.
The targetRole element contains a textual description of the relation. It is recommended that the terms in targetRole be taken from authorized vocabularies.

The latter are also available on demand in case the documents of interest have not been digitised yet. More details on related fees can be found online or by contacting the reading room.

div.p: Term
An element used to specify a descriptive term in accordance with authorized vocabularies or local rules.
[text]
function, legalStatus, localControl, localDescription, mandate, occupation, otherEntityType

term is a required child element of function, legalStatus, localControl, localDescription, mandate, occupation, and otherEntityType, used to specify a descriptive term in accordance with authorized vocabularies or local rules.

term can be repeated within its parent element to include translations of the same term. Use the languageOfElement attribute to identify the language used in each term grouped within a single parent element.
Required, repeatable
Timetable
Opening times and dates of closure of the repository.
closing (0..n), opening (1..n)

Contains opening and closing tags for providing opening hours and dates of closure. Information on opening hours is required. Note that this elemen cannot contain text.

div.p: To Date
A child element of dateRange that records the end point in a range of dates.
[text]
dateRange

audience
Optional (values limited to: external, internal) calendar
Optional certainty
Optional conventionDeclarationReference
Optional era
Optional id
Optional languageOfElement
Optional localType
Optional localTypeDeclarationReference
Optional maintenanceEventReference
Optional notAfter
Optional notBefore
Optional scriptOfElement
Optional standardDate
Optional status
Optional (values limited to: ongoing, unknown) sourceReference
Optional target
Optional f

Use toDate to record the end date in a range of dates, whether they be known, approximate or unknown. The content of the element is intended to be a human-readable, natural language expression of the date. If, however, indexing or other machine processing of dates is desired, the standardDate should be used to record the date in machine-processable form as well. toDate may be omitted from dateRange, or the status attribute used, if the date span is ongoing or the toDate is unknown.

list.item: Use certainty to indicate the degree of precision in the dating, for example, "uncertain" or "approximate".
Use localType to supply a more specific characterization of the start date.
Use notAfter and notBefore to capture the latest and earliest possible dates in machine-processable form in cases when the date is uncertain.
Use standardDate to provide a machine-processable form of the date.
Use status with the values "unknown" or "ongoing" to indicate where part of a date range is unknown, or the date range is ongoing.
Use fromDate to record the starting point of a date range.

div.p: Optional, not repeatable
Tours and sessionsx
Statement on availability of tours and/or sessions offered.
[text]
recreationalServices

Statement on availability of tours (through the archive, through the library, etc) and/or sessions offered explaining how to use an archive (or the archives' research facilities) and possibility to provide additional information.
Optional, repeatable
Conditions of use
Information about use of the materials. May incorporate information (and links) to terms of use, archival law, fee structure, etc.
[text]
access

Information about terms of use for the materials, such as restrictions on printing or downloading content, information on copyright and data protection, and prohibited use. For example, copies can be made for non-commercial purposes only, or copyright exists in these materials and they cannot be copied without special permission.

div.p: Dates of Use
An optional child element of nameEntry and nameEntrySet that provides the dates when the name or names were used for or by the CPF entity being described.
date or dateRange or dateSet (1..1)
nameEntry, nameEntrySet

Within nameEntry, useDates provides the dates during which the name was used for or by the CPF entity. For parallel names (e.g., official forms of the name in different languages and/or scripts), useDates may occur in nameEntrySet rather than in the individual nameEntry elements contained in nameEntrySet.
useDates must include one of date, dateRange, or dateSet.
Optional, repeatable
Work Places
Number of work places (seats) in the searchroom.
computerPlaces (0..n), microfilmPlaces (0..n), num (1..1)
searchroom

Use subelements computerPlaces and microfilmPlaces to specify how many of the work places in total have been fitted with computers, options to connect one's own devices, or to read document digitised as microfilm/microfiche.
Optional, repeatable
Address Line Type
Used to specify the type of address line encoded in addressLine.
Required attribute of addressLine. Use one of the set values to specify the type of address line encoded. Use the attribute localType in order to encode a local type of address line.
county, country, district, municipality, postalCode, postBox, region, street
Agent Type
A required attribute of agent that indicates the type of agent responsible for the creation, modification, or deletion of an EAG instance.

The attribute's value must be set to "human," "machine," or "unknown," and should correspond to the information recorded in agent. For example, if the agent is Jane Marshall, the value of agentType should be set to "human." If the agent is a database, style sheet, or other system, the value of agentType should be set to "machine." The value of agentType may also be set to "unknown" if the agent and/or type of agent cannot be determined.
human, machine, unknown
Audience
An optional attribute that helps control whether the information contained in the element should be available to all viewers or only to repository staff.

Available as global attribute for all elements. The attribute can be set to "external" in repository to allow access to all the information about the entity being described, but specific elements within repository can be set to "internal" to reserve that information for repository access only. This feature is intended to assist application software in restricting access to particular information by explicitly identifying data that is potentially sensitive or may otherwise have a limited audience. Special software capability may be needed, however, to prevent the display or export of an element marked "internal" when a whole institution description is displayed in a networked environment.
external, internal
Base
Optional attribute used to specify a base URI that is different to the base URI of the EAG instance.

Using the optional attribute base allows any relative URIs provided on attributes of a specific element, or its descendants, to be resolved using the URI provided in that element's or its parent element's base.
Available on control, description, eag, identity, relations, repository, repositories, and sources.
anyURI
Calendar
System of reckoning time, such as Gregorian calendar or Julian calendar.
Suggested values include, but are not limited to, "gregorian" and "julian". Available in date, fromDate, and toDate.
NMTOKEN
Certainty
The level of confidence for a date.
The optional attribute certainty provides a level of confidence for the information given in date, fromDate, or toDate, e.g., approximate or circa.
NMTOKEN
Contact Line Type
Used to specify the type of contact line encoded in contactLine.
Required attribute in contactLine. Use one of the set values to specify the type of contact line encoded. Use the attribute localType in order to encode a local type of contact line.
directions, email, fax, homepage, mobileNumber, phoneNumber
Convention Declaration Reference
Use conventionDeclarationReference to provide a direct link to a conventionDeclaration element within control.

The attribute can be used to link to a convention or rule applied in the creation of the content of a specific element, such as a convention or rule that prescribes a method for converting one script into another script (transliteration), or a national, international or other rule that governs the construction of an EAG name.

This optional attribute is available in all elements in the identity area (except repositoryType), in the description area, in relations (except for objectXMLWrap), and in the overarching repository element.
IDREFS
Coordinate System
A code for a system used to express geographic coordinates.

A code for a system used to express geographic coordinates, for example WGS84, (World Geodetic System), OSGB36 (Ordnance Survey Great Britain), or ED50 (European Datum). Required in geographicCoordinates.
token
Country Code
A unique code representing a country.

Content of the optional attribute should be a code taken from ISO 3166-1 Codes for the Representation of Names of Countries and their Subdivisions, column A2, or another controlled list, as specified in the countryEncoding attribute in control. Available in maintenanceAgency, placeName, and repositoryId.
NMTOKEN
Country Encoding
The authoritative source or rules for values supplied in countryCode.

The authoritative source or rules for values supplied in countryCode in maintenanceAgency, placeName, and repositoryId. If the value "otherCountryEncoding" is selected an alternate code list should be specified in conventionDeclaration. This optional attribute is available only in control.
iso3166-1, otherCountryEncoding
Coverage
Clarifies whether a statement of extent relates to the entire holdings of an institution or only a part of them.

Optional attribute that specifies whether the extent information given for the holdings of the institution being described applies to their holdings as a "whole" or only in "part". Allows to e.g. have two parallel extent statements giving an institution's complete holdings once in linear metres and once in squaremetres or to provide two partial statements of extent to combine an institution's analog and digital holdings while using different units of measurement as appropriate.
part, whole
Date Encoding
The authoritative source or rules for values provided in standardDate, standardDateTime, notBefore, and notAfter.

The authoritative source or rules for values provided in standardDate and related attributes in date, fromDate and toDate as well as standardDateTime in eventDateTime. If the value "otherDateEncoding" is selected an alternate code list should be specified in conventionDeclaration. This optional attribute is available only in control.
iso8601, otherDateEncoding
Level of Detail
Provides information about the level of detail of the entity’s description within the EAG instance.

An optional attribute within control, used to provide information about the level of detail in accordance with relevent description guidelines and/or rules of the entity's description, from a fixed set of values.
basic, extended, minimal
Era
Period during which years are numbered and dates reckoned.

Period during which years are numbered and dates reckoned, such as CE (Common Era) or BCE (Before Common Era). Suggested values include "ce" and "bce". This optional attribute is available in date, fromDate, and toDate.
NMTOKEN
Hypertext Reference
The address for a remote resource.

The optional href attribute takes the form of a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI). Available in access, accessConditions, accessibility, advancedOrders, building, closing, contactLine, exhibition, image, internetAccess, multilingualServices, opening, otherServices, photographAllowance, readersTicket, reference, refreshment, representation, researchServices, socialMedia, source, toursSessions, useConditions, and workPlaces.
anyURI

div.p: ID
A unique identifer to name the element.

An identifier that must be unique within the current document and is used to name the element so that it can be referred to, or referenced from, somewhere else. This facilitates building links between the element and other elements of the current document as well as other resources. Available optionally in all elements of EAG.
Use target, conventionDeclarationReference, localTypeDeclarationReference, maintenanceEventReference, or sourceReference to link to an id attribute of another element within the EAG instance.
ID
Identity Type
Indicates whether the identity is given or acquired.
The optional identityType may occur on identity.
acquired, given
Language Code
The code for the language(s) used in the EAG instance.

Content of the attribute should be a code taken from ietf-bcp-47, ISO 639-1, ISO 639-2b, ISO 639-3, or another controlled list, as specified in the languageEncoding attribute in control. Required in languageDeclaration.
NMTOKEN
Language Encoding
Specifies which standard list of codes is used to identify the language of the EAG instance.

The codes themselves are specified in languageCode in languageDeclaration and languageOfElement in all non-empty elements. Available in control. If the value "otherLanguageEncoding" is selected an alternate code list should be specified in conventionDeclaration. This optional attribute is available only in control.
ietf-bcp-47, iso639-1, iso639-2b, iso639-3, otherLanguageEncoding
Language of Element
Indicates the language of the content of an element.

Content of the attribute should be a code taken from ietf-bcp-47, ISO 639-1, ISO 639-2b, ISO 639-3, or another controlled list, as specified in the languageEncoding attribute in control. May be used consistently in a multi-lingual repository description to specify which elements are written in which language. Optionally available on all non-empty elements.
NMTOKEN

A URI that characterizes the nature of the remote resource to which a linking element refers.

div.p: Link Title
Viewable caption of a link text.

Information that serves as a viewable caption which explains to users the part that a resource plays in a link. May be useful for meeting accessibility requirements when rendering content in a web browser. Optionally available next to href in Available in access, accessConditions, accessibility, advancedOrders, building, closing, contactLine, exhibition, image, internetAccess, multilingualServices, opening, otherServices, photographAllowance, readersTicket, reference, refreshment, representation, researchServices, socialMedia, source, toursSessions, useConditions, and workPlaces.
token

eag:contact.eag:contactLine: Buslinien 2 und 12 (Richtung Karthause) bis Bundesarchiv (von Haltestelle Hauptbahnhof West am Hauptbahnhof-Nebenausgang an der Simmerner Straße).

div.p: List Type
Specifies the type of list.
An ordered list is a numbered or lettered list; an unordered list is one in which sequence is not critical (e.g., a bulleted list). Optionally available only on list.
ordered, unordered

eag:list.eag:head: List of ministers of May Memorial Unitarian Universalist Church

div.p: Local Type
This optional attribute provides a means to narrow the semantics of an element, or provide semantics for elements that are primarily structural or semantically weak.

The value of localType may be from a local or generally used external vocabulary. While the value of localType may be any string, to facilitate exchange of data, it is recommended that the value be either the URI or the preferred label for a term defined in a formal vocabulary (e.g., SKOS), which is identified by an absolute URI, and is resolvable to a web resource that describes the semantic scope and use of the value.

Local conventions or controlled vocabularies used in localType may be declared in localTypeDeclaration within control.localTypeDeclarationReference should always be used alongside localType to provide a direct link to the localTypeDeclaration.
token
Local Type Declaration Reference
Use localTypeDeclarationReference to provide a direct link to a localTypeDeclaration element within control from another element using localType within the EAG instance.
localTypeDeclarationReference should always be used when localType is used, in order to link to the local type declaration.
IDREFS
Maintenance Event Reference
Use maintenanceEventReference to provide a direct link to a maintenanceEvent element within maintenanceHistory.
The attribute can be used to link to a maintenance event in order to verify any assertion added to the repository’s description.

The attribute is optionally available in all elements in the identity area (except repositoryType), in the description area, in relations (except for objectXMLWrap), and in the overarching repository element.
IDREFS
Maintenance Event Type
A required attribute of maintenanceEvent that provides a controlled list of values for recording the type of maintenance activity.

list.item: cancelled: marks an instance as not current (obsolete or rejected), but retained for reference
created: the initial creation of the EAG instance
deleted: indication that the instance has been deleted from the system
derived: indicates that the instance was derived from another descriptive system
revised: any type of general modification to the EAG instance
unknown: when the type of event is not known
updated: when an instance has been brought up to date with significant changes to the repository's description or to the version of EAG used

div.p: cancelled, created, deleted, derived, revised, unknown, updated
Maintenance Status
The current drafting status of the EAG instance.

The maintenance status must occur on control. As an EAG instance is modified or other events happen to it (as recorded in the maintenanceHistory element), the maintenance status should also be updated to reflect the current drafting status.

On first creation the status would be "new", which on revision can be changed to "revised". Because it is important to be clear about what has happened to EAG instances, particularly when sharing and making links between them, a number of status values are available for instances that are no longer current. An instance that is simply deleted from a system can be given the status "deleted", but in cases where an instance is marked as not current (obsolete or rejected) but kept for reference then it should be given the status "cancelled". If an instance is deleted because it has become superseded by two or more records then its status should be given as "deletedSplit", while if it has simply been replaced by a new instance then "deletedReplaced" is the appropriate status value. If an instance is deleted because it has been merged with another instance, its status should be given as "deletedMerged". A "derived" status value is available to indicate that the instance was derived from another descriptive system.
cancelled, deleted, deletedMerged, deletedReplaced, deletedSplit, derived, new, revised
Not After
A standard numerical form of an approximate date for which a latest possible date is known.
Optionally available in date, fromDate, and toDate. It is recommended that notAfter values follow ISO 8601 or another standard date format as specified in dateEncoding.
token
Not Before
A standard numerical form of an approximate date for which an earliest possible date is known.
Optionally available in date, fromDate, and toDate. It is recommended that notBefore values follow ISO 8601 or another standard date format as specified in dateEncoding.
token
Other Unit
Allows the inclusion of other formats or units specified in citedRange and num.

Use otherUnit when using the parallel unit with the value "otherUnit" within citedRange or num. You can then include any unit of measurement that would be applicable to the respective context as the value of otherUnit.
token
Preferred Form
Attribute that specifies whether or not a name provides the preferred form of the repository's name for display purposes.

Attribute that specifies whether or not a nameEntry provides the preferred form of the name of the EAG entity for display purposes in a given context. Use the value "true" if the name entry is preferred for any display purposed.
This optional attribute is only available in nameEntry.
false, true
Publication Status
The current publication status of the EAG instance.

The publication status may occur on control to indicate the current publication status of the EAG instance, whether in process, approved or published. As an EAG instance is modified or other events happen to it (as recorded in the maintenanceHistory element), the publication status should also be updated.

A newly created EAG instance will usually start with a publication status of "inProcess". This partial and preliminary status will be applicable as long as the author or the creating agency is working on the document. Depending on the context, the document might first reach a pre-publication level, awaiting approval e.g. by a higher level manager or an authorizing agency. Once such approval has been given, the status "approved" could be assigned for internal purposes while the EAG instance is not publicly available yet. When the EAG instance has been published on the institution’s own website or via the authorizing agency, the status "published" can be assigned.
approved, inProcess, published
Question
Question of existence or availability of certain services and facilities.
A required attribute with all services and facilities an institution with archival holdings might offer to its users.

When access, accessibility, advancedOrders, exhibition, internetAccess, library, multilingualServices, otherServices, photographAllowance, readersTicket, reproductionServices, restorationLaboratory,refreshment, researchServices, searchroom, toursSessions, or workPlaces are used, the attribute provides an option to generally indicate the existence or availability of these services and facilities with the values "yes", "yes (conditions apply)", or "no", but to leave the elements themselves empty and to e.g. make use of the optional linking attributes to link to existing websites for more information.
no, yes, yes (conditions apply)
Repository Code
A unique code for the institution being described.

A unique code required in repositoryId identifying the insitution being described. Ideally, the code used here is the institution's registered ISIL code. The Danish Agency for Culture acts as international Registration Authority to maintain the standard and its registry, with many countries having national ISIL agencies in addition. When ISIL codes are issued by national agencies, they always start with the two-letter country code according to ISO 3166-1 followed by a hyphen-minus and by the identifier assigned by that country's ISIL agency.

In case an institution does not have a registered ISIL code or cannot register for one easily, it is recommended that the code given in repositoryCode at least complies generally with the structure set out in the International Standard Identifier for Libraries and Related Organisations (ISIL), ISO 15511. This means, that the code needs to be alphanumeric, with a maximum of 16 characters, only including a-z, A-Z, 0-9, solidus, hyphen-minus or colon as valid symbols.

Other unique codes for the institution with archival holdings can be used in repositoryCode in general, but only when having specified another controlled list in the repositoryEncoding attribute in control.
NMTOKEN
Repository Encoding
The authoritative source or rules for values supplied in agencyCode and repositoryCode.

The authoritative source or rules for values supplied in agencyCode and repositoryCode. If the value "otherRepositoryEncoding" is selected an alternate code list should be specified in conventionDeclaration. Optionally available only in control.
iso15511, otherRepositoryEncoding
Script Code
The code for the writing system, or script, used in the EAG instance.
Content of the attribute should be a code taken from ISO 15924, or another controlled list, as specified in the scriptEncoding attribute in control. Optionally available in languageDeclaration.
NMTOKEN
Script Encoding
The authoritative source or rules for values supplied in scriptOfElement and scriptCode.

The authoritative source or rules for values supplied in scriptOfElement and scriptCode. If the value "otherScriptEncoding" is selected, an alternate code list should be specified in conventionDeclaration. Optionally available only in control.
iso15924, otherScriptEncoding
Script of Element
Indicates the writing script of the content of an element (e.g., Cyrillic, Katakana).

Content should be taken from ISO 15924, or another controlled list, as specified in the scriptEncoding attribute in control. May be used consistently in a multi-lingual finding aid to specify which elements are written in which script. Optionally available on all non-empty elements.
NMTOKEN
Source Reference
Use sourceReference to provide a direct link to a source element within sources in control from an element within the EAG instance that uses the source.
The attribute can be used to reference any detailed information about the described entity with a source.

The attribute is optionally available in all elements in the identity area (except repositoryType), in the description area, in relations (except for objectXMLWrap), and in the overarching repository element.
IDREFS
Standard Date
The standardized form of a date.

The standardized form of a date expressed in date, fromDate, and toDate. It is recommended that standardDate values follow ISO 8601, for example, 2011-07-22, 1963, or 1912-11, or another standard date format as specified in dateEncoding.
token
Standard Date and Time
Standardized form of a date, or date and time in eventDateTime.

An ISO 8601-compliant form of the date, or date and time, of a specific maintenance event expressed in eventDateTime. For example, 2021-12-31, 2021, 2021-12, 2021-12-31T23:59:59. Optionally available only in eventDateTime.

Constrained to the following patterns: YYYY-MM-DD, YYYY-MM, YYYY, or YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss [with optional timezone offset from UTC in the form of [+|-][hh:mm], or "Z" to indicate the dateTime is UTC. Similarly, no timezone implies the dateTime is UTC.]
Status
Attribute that provides controlled terminology detailing the status of certain elements.

status provides controlled terminology detailing the status of specific elements. The terms available for status are defined in closed lists that vary by element. Optionally available only in agencyCode, date, fromDate, nameEntry, otherAgencyCode, repositoryId, and toDate.
Values in agencyCode, nameEntry, otherAgencyCode, repositoryId: alternative, authorized
Values in date, fromDate: unknown
Values in toDate: ongoing, unknown
Style
Used to specify a rendering style for a string. It is recommended that the value conforms to W3C CSS.

The style attribute may only occur on span. In a limited number of contexts that accommodate discursive description, span with style may be used to identify an arbitrary string that is intended to be rendered in a specific style. It is highly recommended that the value of style be expressed as a W3C CSS style to facilitate interoperability.
normalizedString

eag:biogHist.eag:p: 1978: The Federal Archives are given the task of acting as a central film archive for all German film productions as a result of an administration agreement covering the Association of Cinema Library Facilities.

1988: With the passing of the Law on the Preservation and Use of Federal Archival Documents (Bundesarchivgesetz) on the 6th of January 1988, general access to the Federal Archives and the responsibilities of the Federal Archives are for the first time placed on a sound legal footing.

1989: With the passing of the Law on the Central Archiving of Documents Concerning Legislation Governing the After-effects of War, the Federal Archives set up a central Lastenausgleichsarchiv (archives on equalization of burdens) in Bayreuth.

div.p: Target
A pointer to the ID of another element.
Used to create internal links within an XML instance. Optionally available in all elements except eag.
IDREFS
Target Type
Identifies the type of entity that is related to the repository being described.
Required attribute within targetEntity which identifies the type of entity that is related to the repository being described.
agent, corporateBody, family, function, person, resource
Unit
Defines the format or unit that is specified in citedRange and num.

Use unit optionally with the value "otherUnit" and the parallel otherUnit to document the format or unit that is specified in citedRange, for example page number ("pageNumber") or volume number ("volumeNumber").

Using unit within num is required. Select a value from the predefined list, which can be applied depending on the context. E.g. use "linearmetre" when used within lengthOfShelves or extent, "squaremetre" or "cubicmetre" when used within repositoryArea, "megabyte", "gigabyte", "terabyte", "petabyte", or "exabyte" when used within extent for digital holdings, and "site" when used within workPlaces, computerPlaces, or microfilmPlaces.
token
cubicmetre, exabyte, gigabyte, linearmetre, megabyte, otherUnit, petabyte, site, squaremetre, terabyte
Value
Defines the type of repository described in the EAG instance.
Required attribute within the repositoryType element that defines the type of repository described in the EAG instance.

businessArchives, communityArchives, internationalArchives, localArchives, nationalArchives, nonUniversityEducationArchives, personalAndFamilyArchives, regionalArchives, religiousInstitutionsArchives, specialisedGovernmentArchives, specialisedNongovernmentalArchives, universityArchives
Value URI
An attribute for including a URI identifying the resource to be used as the element's value.
Use the optional valueURI attribute to provide the URI identifying the authority resource to be used as the element's content. Available in all elements that can contain any type of entity.
anyURI
Vocabulary Source
An attribute for identifying a vocabulary that is the source of the element's value.
Use the optional attribute to provide a name or title of the authority or vocabulary source of the element’s content given in valueURI. Available in all elements that can contain any type of entity.
token
Vocabulary Source URI
An optional attribute for including a URI identifying the vocabulary source for the element's value.
Use the optional attribute to provide the URI of the authority or vocabulary source given in vocabularySource. Available in all elements that can contain any type of entity.
anyURI
